title: Cardano Hub Venezuela
description: Venezuelan crypto adoption is happening. Now is the time to escalate Cardano's presence and bring ADA into the hands of its citizens.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal addresses the challenge very effectively in that it intends to create both an online as well as in-person hub in a community in Venezuela to educate and network about Cardano topics. The proposal would add one community hub and create realistic options to onboard new members, including developers to the Cardano Network. The fact that people from the community would actively take on responsibilities is an important part of empowering new people to find their way into the Cardano eco system and is good in the way that it does not "talk down" on peole but actively enables them to contribute. This is very much how Catalyst works, as well.
f6_assessments.q1:
The described relevant experience would match the proposed initiative. The budget that is broken down would work with what the proposer describes. I find it difficult that a main part of the funding is allocated to giveaway systems, especially with the proposer mentioning "airdrops" - pretty much every video that Charles does and every anti-scam video about ADA includes "there are no giveaways - there are no airdrops". So if this proposer aims to onboard new members, a reward system is definitely useful but if he introduces new users to airdrops, they might fall for scams in the future. Information about outreach and programs on promoting the hub is missing.
The proposer is too vague in what this hub is wanting to achieve. The proposal would have benefittet from some relevant information on the intended content of the hub, "how to trade ADA", "how to avoid scams", "how to propose in Catalyst" and so on. Without this information the prior commitment on this topic seems less valid. Information on the expansion of the project with several hubs points to scalability, but it not likely to be implemented within this challenge and would need further explanation as to what that means and how these new initiatives would receive funding. Generally, the idea is good and implementation of sorts is highly likely, however given the information in this proposal, some of the numbers seem very positive and I would need further information as to why the proposer thinks a hub would attract that many people.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer does not give relevant information that would enhance auditability, like documentation. Additionally, the proposer should specify what "donations" means. Generally, those parts of the proposal should be documented. The numbers that the proposer provided show a clear goal and they would be auditable - however, the proposal would have to (again) add documentation on how he would support auditability. The milestones do not include topics, just how many members the proposer would want to onboard. He should differentiate between in-person hubs and the online presence. An in-person hub with 5000+ members would not be financially manageable with the proposed funding, so the roadmap is missing relevant information on that. Additionally, information on outreach and social media presence to reach the targeted audience is missing. No information about content of the hubs is given, this makes it less auditable - the proposer should add relevant information on what they are planning to provide to the people.

f6_assessments.q0:
-This proposal addresses directly the challenge, creating Venezuelan community hub with a broad program in education, workshops and  meetups, as well as an active online presence.
-The size of the project team and representation of individual members are not included in the proposal, this is one important matter that should be added to the proposal.
I agree that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
-The plan of this proposal is very clear written and detailed, expressing details of a twelve-month activity.
-They intend to build an online and in-person community in the capital city of Caracas.
-The budget and goals are clearly described, with a complete, aesthetic timeline.
-Under budget there is stated allocation of $5000 for airdrops, giveaways, special prizes and donations. I am not fully sure if funding of giveaways and special prizes is acceptable use of funds by the Catalyst Cardano community. I don't have confidence to make a clear statement on this matter, thus I recommend to address it and seek guidance from Catalyst Circle. What I can say with confidence is that this should not be a limitation to successfully implement this project. My suggestion is to exclude these funds from the proposal and seek donations and sponsorships outside from Cardano Catalyst ecosystem. These sponsorships should follow Cardano Catalyst community guidelines.
I strongly agree that it is highly likely that this proposal will be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2:
-The timeline describes success by membership count in each consecutive three months periods. In addition count of online and in-person gatherings positively executed. Future local Cardano conferences are listed in the second half of the 12-moth period.
-Public launch date is estimated to commence on January 3rd 2022.
-This timeline and goals describe a healthy natural growth, if successfully executed, this hub could represent one of the major Cardano hubs in Latin America
-The metrics for the success of this proposal are clearly defined.
I strongly agree that this proposal provides complete and comprehensible information to assess the progress in attaining its stated goals.

f6_assessments.q0: The author has a plan to introduce Cardano to wider audience in Venezuela. With Spanish as his mother tongue, it can address way more people over the world online. However, the statements in proposal are very general which may imply it's just a basic idea without further analysis of local needs.
f6_assessments.q1: As stated previously, the plan is a bit too general. Also the experience of possible team members is not mentioned, we don't get to know any names related to this project or their involvement in Cardano ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q2: KPIs are presented and they should be easy to assess. At first sight they should be possible to reach if the project is executed properly.

f6_assessments.q0: I am unable to understand exactly how they plan to create this community. They simply say they plan to build an online and in person community. They say that they will utilize meetup and telegram groups, but these already exist and have large followings for Cardano. Their goal is to add 5000 users by next year, but most Cardano networking groups already grow at a much faster pace than that. Based on the write up, I am not sure if this is supposed to be a website that they use to build this, or what the general plan would be. I think that building communities in latin america is a great idea and something we should do, but based on this proposal, I am not confident that this team will get that done with their funds.
f6_assessments.q1: There is not much of a plan presented for anyone to feel confident in its success. The plan is extremely vague and basically says that they will create an online and in person community somehow. There is no information about how this community will be structured and there is no information about how they will get the community interested and wanting to participate. Anyone can create a telegram group, but a detailed explanation about how they will reach people who are not already involved in Cardano and get them to join this is not included, and would be crucial to having confidence that they would be able to carry this out.
f6_assessments.q2: This is my area of expertise, having worked in audit over the last decade and currently have a project I am building for Cardano dealing specifically with audit. While I do not believe that this proposal is very detailed in how they will achieve their goals, they have listed out goals and metrics that would be easy to track and audit against. All zoom meetings could provide the number of people who signed up, The in person and online meetings would be easy enough to verify with some type of attendance list that they could take for each meeting along with agenda's and other materials that could be provided to verify the meetings actually taking place. They also provide desired number of participants over the next year, which would be easy to vouch and track as well.

f6_assessments.q0: Building a community in venezuella is a good match with the challenge. The only issue I see with the proposal is the lack of clear plan. The proposer could  write down exactly how they intend to build the community.
f6_assessments.q1: Due to the lack of a clear plan, I don't see how this proposal can get implemented. Building a community online and in person is quite vague in my opinion. I wish that the proposer can refine his proposal for future funds.
f6_assessments.q2: This proposal is vague. There is a lack of a detailed plan and path to the goal. The proposer does not specify how he intend to build the community online and offline. This project will not be easily auditable.

f6_assessments.q0: No information is added to help understandplans for the hub so the proposal remains very abstract.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer team states that it has the necessary experience. However, they did not provide any links or references to support this statement. My recommendation for a future proposal is to add this information so that the voters are able to validate the experience. The budget provided is very general and therefore I cannot say whether it is appropriate or not
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer provides a step-by-step plan for the implementation with clear milestones and a defined time horizon. There are also several metrics that measure the success of this project

solution: Building a Cardano community project focused on the educational pursuits of its members, led by Venezuelan collaborators themselves.
experience: Community management, activism, blockchain development and education, including the hosting of workshops and cryptocurrency meetups.
